Award.AwardTitle: CEDAR: Analysis of High Resolution Stratospheric Observations of Polar Mesospheric Clouds
Award.AbstractNarration:
A unique data set consisting of high-resolution optical images of Polar Mesospheric Clouds (PMCs) observed from a stratospheric balloon platform in January of 2013 will be analyzed. PMCs have proven to be excellent tracers of dynamics in the mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT). Complex morphological structures in their brightness distribution provide observable consequences of the deposition of energy and momentum by atmospheric gravity waves (GW) in the MLT. This high-resolution data set of optical images provides a unique window into the poorly understood instability and turbulent dynamics on the smallest scales (between roughly a meter and a few km). Through this analysis, morphological features identified in individual images will be compared with those predicted in numerical models in order to identify key dynamical features present in the data on these small scales.
Despite the limited field of view available in these images, the analysis of this data set will enable the identification of features that show a range of dynamics, providing evidence for transitional scales and instability accompanying GW breaking or Kelvin-Helmholtz instabilities. It will also enable the identification of features that place bounds on the local Reynolds number, and therefore the background turbulence level. This project will provide research opportunities for graduate, undergraduate, and high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project enabled exploration of the atmospheric processes leading to turbulence throughout the atmosphere. Turbulence sources, intermittency, and influences are only partially understood at present, despite their importance to many aspects of human activity. Turbulence plays a significant role in the diurnal variability of surface temperatures that significantly impact power and energy consumption for heating and cooling. Turbulence and its dynamical sources cause commercial flight disruptions and have been identified as the causes of multiple aircraft crashes. Turbulence and its sources are also major contributors to the structure and variability of the atmosphere from the surface to very high altitudes that have major influences on weather and climate, which impact ~30% of the global economy. Our lack of a more quantitative understanding of turbulence and its influences contributes to relatively poor medium-range (a few weeks) weather prediction, improvement of which would potentially save trillions of $$ each year.

Research under this funding contributed to revolutionary new observations and improved modeling addressing the causes and consequences of multiple turbulence sources and responses. Surprisingly, the observations addressed by these efforts occurred at a very high altitude, roughly 50 miles above Earth’s surface, because the instability and turbulence processes of interest more generally occur at large spatial scales and are easier to observe and quantify that at any other altitude. This is because the atmosphere at this altitude hosts an unusual ice cloud layer that is very thin, occurring only under full day-time conditions at high latitudes in the summer hemisphere. These polar mesosphere clouds (PMCs), also called noctilucent clouds (NLCs) when viewed from the ground with the Sun illuminating them from below the horizon. They act as remarkable tracers of the dynamics that have durations of 10’s of minutes to an hour or more. Imaging turbulence dynamics over these durations enabled us to diagnose them in detail, perform parallel modeling guiding our interpretation, and prepare a number of scientific papers reporting the results.

The project contributed analyses and modeling of PMC turbulence events and to preparation for a NASA PMC Turbulence Experiment (PMC Turbo) flown aboard a long-duration balloon that floated at an altitude of 23 miles (three times as high as commercial aircraft) in the stratosphere on a flight from northern Sweden to NE Canada for almost 6 days in July 2018. A suite of 7 high-resolution imagers and a Rayleigh lidar measuring vertical profiles of the PMC layer brightness assembled a large data base that has resulted in multiple scientific papers to date, and which will remain available for use in additional research efforts in the future.
